pages:
ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK  TAR:INO 35150 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
 (Cofinanced by the Government  of the United Kingdom) 
 
TO THE 
 
REPUBLIC OF INDONESIA 
 
FOR  
 
STRENGTHENING CIVIL SOCIETY PARTICIPATION  
 
IN THE DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, AND MONITORING OF  
 
ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK PROJECTS 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
August 2003

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of  31 July 2003) 
 
Currency Unit –  Rupiah (Rp) 
Rp1.00 =  $ 0.000111 
$1.00 =  Rp 8535.00 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BAPPEDA  –  Regional Development Planning Agency 
  BAPPENAS  –  National Development Planning Agency 
  BPS  –  Central Bureau of Statistics 
  CSO  –  civil society organizations 
  CSP  –  country strategy and program 
  DG-CRE  –  Director General of Community and Rural Empowerment, 
Ministry of Home Affairs 
  EA  –  Executing Agency 
  ICT  –  information and communications technology 
  IRM  –   Indonesia Resident Mission (ADB) 
  JICA  –  Japan International Cooperation Agency 
  MOHA  –  Ministry of Home Affairs 
  NGO  –  non government organizations 
  NGOC    Non Government Organization Center (ADB) 
  PMO  –  Project management office 
  RWG  –  regional working group 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
(i)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Luddin, Indonesia Resident Mission.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  January  2001,  Indonesia  launched  a  decentralization  program  that  transferred 
substantial authority and resources to regional, especially district governments, creating an 
urgent need for regional good governance mechanisms. One important aspect of encouraging 
good  governance  is  increasing  the  involvement  of  civil  society  in  decision-making  and  in 
monitoring of public sector activities.  
 
2.  The  Country  Strategy  and  Program  (CSP)  for  Indonesia  adopted  in  2002,  and  the 
poverty reduction strategy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) call for closer cooperation 
between  civil  society  and  government,  and  improved  transparency  of,  and  participation  in  
decision making process in the Government. This is to be achieved within the scope of a 
geographic focus to ensure maximum use of ADB resources to reduce poverty. Success of the 
geographic focus will depend on ensuring local good governance practices. Ownership and 
commitment of regional stakeholders, civil society, and regional governments, which include 
both provincial and district governments, must be established. Strong, effective civil society 
organizations (CSO), especially non-governmental organizations (NGOs), will be needed for this 
purpose.1 
 
3.  To  establish  closer  linkages  between  ADB  and  civil  society,  particularly  in  the 
geographic  focus  areas,  the  CSO  working  group  was  established  at  the  ADB  Indonesia 
Resident Mission (IRM) in March 2001.2  In order to deepen the interaction with civil society, an 
advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  project–-Strengthening  Civil  Society  Participation  in  the 
Design, Implementation, and Monitoring of ADB Projects–-was accordingly programmed for 
2002 based on the request of the Government. IRM staff undertook a fact-finding Mission in 
June-August 2002, consulting with government officials at all levels and a wide spectrum of 
CSOs on the TA design and scope.3 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Indonesia’s  decentralization  process  transfers  responsibility  for  many  areas  of 
development to regional governments, including education, health, minor infrastructure, and the 
protection  of  some  environmental  resources.  Potentially  this  process  allows  for  more 
participatory approaches in development planning than in the past when decision-making was 
concentrated at the central government level. CSOs can play an important role in this new 
paradigm as they have been active in communities for decades and have valuable information 
concerning local development needs and priorities. 
 
5.  For ensuring sustainability and ownership, all projects must involve interaction with a 
broad range of stakeholders, including regional governments and legislatures, and civil society.  
Since its establishment in March 2001, the CSO working group has been meeting regularly with 
ADB project staff at the Indonesian Resident Mission (IRM) engaged in administering and 
processing loans and TAs to review sector or regional issues. This has provided a mechanism 
to take into account the views of civil society at every stage of the project cycle. 
 
                                                 
1  “Geographic Focus” is explained in the CSP 2003-2005 document (para 50-55). 
2  Supporting this, IRM engaged a full-time NGO-public information officer in May-2002. 
3 The TA was first listed in ADB Business Opportunities in 29 April 2002. The first draft concept paper was discussed 
with the CSO Working Group for IRM in July 2001. Follow up discussions on the TA were conducted with regional 
CSOs in Bandung in December 2001, in Medan in March 2002, and in Yogyakarta in June 2002.

2   
6.  Although the CSO working group provides a good avenue for consultation with civil 
society, CSO involvement in development activities is generally limited. Lack of access to 
information and understanding of external funding agencies’ policies and procedures on the part 
of  CSOs  has  hindered  strengthening  of  cooperation  among  them.  Capacity  weaknesses, 
especially  affecting  sustainability  of  CSO  activities,  also  hinder  CSO  involvement  in 
development planning and implementation. Lack of institutional structures to coordinate efforts 
between CSOs and government agencies and among CSOs is a further problem. 
 
7.  CSOs in Indonesia address a variety of felt needs.  Some focus more on advocacy of  
issues  at  a  macro  level  such  as  debt  reduction,  governance,  anti-corruption,  labor  and 
environment.    Other  CSOs  work  in  specific  sectors  such  as  education,  health,  and  rural 
development.  While some are mainly based in Jakarta, others have large networks throughout 
Indonesia.  However, on the whole, while the process of democratization has led to an upsurge 
in the numbers of CSOs and their activities, they are not sufficiently equipped technically and 
organizationally to play a meaningful role in development as yet.  Their capacity building needs 
are numerous.   
 
8.  ADB’s operations are more directly relevant for CSOs functioning in sectors.   These 
CSOs need to be brought more closely into ADB operations throughout the project cycle.  CSO 
involvement in the design, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of ADB projects can 
ensure that these will bring tangible benefits to the intended beneficiaries, which can help 
ensure strong local ownership and sustainability. With experience in ADB projects, CSOs can 
also strengthen their capacity for cooperation in local development and governance. 
 
9.  During ADB’s consultations with regional civil-society representatives, CSOs requested 
the establishment of regional organizations similar to the Jakarta based CSO working group, 
especially in the provinces falling within the CSP’s geographic focus. The regional working 
groups (RWGs) will interact with regional governments on development matters, particularly 
relating to ADB projects.  Such interaction could involve, for example, participating in project 
related discussions, informing the ADB and Government about problems and issues associated 
with implementation, and in benefit monitoring and evaluation workshops.  Exposure to ADB 
projects will also help RWGs build capacity in project implementation and administration. When 
given training and other capacity-building inputs, some under the TA, RWGs are expected to 
ensure that externally funded projects will have positive impacts and involve a wider range of 
stakeholder groups of people in key decision making.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The short-term goal of the TA is to develop a mechanism to fully integrate civil-society 
representatives as key regional players and stakeholders in ADB assisted projects. The long-
term objective of the TA is to enable CSOs to contribute to participatory development at the 
regional level.

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Establishment of CSO Regional Working Groups 
11.  RWGs will act as consultative bodies on general development issues such as poverty 
reduction and regional economic needs, as well as on specific issues related to ADB projects.  
RWGs are expected to have regular consultations with regional governments and ADB staff 
during project design and implementation.  RWGs will be kept informed of all ADB activities and 
are expected to provide information and feedback at all stages of the project cycle –- design, 
processing and implementation.  RWGs will also coordinate their   members’ activities in these   
areas. The existing Jakarta-based CSO Working Group will play a major role in establishing and 
supporting their operations. 
 
12.  Three pilot, provincial RWGs will be established during the TA implementation, initially in 
provinces where ADB operations will be concentrated,4 where ADB-CSO cooperation already 
exists or where significant numbers of ADB projects are ongoing.5  Interaction of ADB staff with 
civil society at the regional level is an important element in capacity building for participating 
groups and will provide valuable inputs for ADB operations.  
 
13.  The TA will determine the criteria for CSO selection, and modalities of functioning and 
interaction with ADB staff and regional governments. Some general criteria for CSO selection 
have been identified during TA processing such as working experience with funding agencies 
and substantial activities in sectors that are the focus of ADB operations in the CSP.  The 
potential for RWGs to coordinate the activities of CSOs will be explored using ADB’s experience 
with coordination mechanisms in the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR)-9000 INO: 
Assisting Girl Street Children at Risk of Sexual Abuse. This activity supported a coordination 
mechanism among NGOs implementing the project in Yogyakarta, enhancing their ability to 
help project beneficiaries.  The TA will advise on the expected financial and capacity building 
needs, such as training for CSO working groups, and coordinating inputs from ADB and other 
sources. 
 
2.  Capacity Building and Training Activities for Civil Society Organizations 
 
14.  Capacity building activities will be conducted under the TA to improve the ability of CSOs 
to contribute to project design, management, implementation, monitoring and evaluation, and to 
work closely with regional governments. Some limited training will be provided to CSOs for   
general  institutional  development  (e.g.  supporting  improved  business  planning,  project 
formulation, and fund raising).  Materials on these topics will be developed in the Indonesian 
language and made available through the IRM web site.  A core set of trainers from civil society 
will be trained during TA implementation and the learning process will be continued through 
training of trainers.  Training will include relevant regional Government staff as resource persons 
and CSO representatives so as to achieve a participatory approach.  
 
                                                 
4 The CSP’s geographic focus includes the provinces of West Java, Banten, Central Java, East Java, Yogyakarta, 
South Sumatra, North Sumatra, West Nusa Tenggara,  Southeast Sulawesi,  and Lampung. 
5  One RWG will be established in Yogyakarta to build on strong ADB-NGO activities, including the JFPR 9000 – INO: 
Assisting Girl Street Children at Risk of Sexual Abuse. Two other RWGs are proposed to be established in 
Bandung, West Java; and Medan, North Sumatra.   Discussions on the TA have already been conducted in these 
two provinces with local governments and CSOs. Final selection of RWG location will be completed after 
consultant selection and further local consultation.

4   
15  The  TA  will  help  maintain  a  regional  CSO  database6,  which  will  build  on  existing 
database  of  Indonesian  CSOs  published  by  other  organizations  including  external  funding 
agencies such as JICA. The TA will identify and help development-oriented CSOs that have 
sector  or  technical  capabilities  and  regional  interests.    The  database  will  be  useful  to 
government agencies, CSOs, and ADB staff, enhancing cooperation and coordination among 
them.  The TA will explore avenues to ensure that such databases will be maintained, including 
through public-private partnerships.  
 
16.  The TA will also disseminate information on ADB policy, procedures, and operations to 
build  civil  society  capacity  to  support  good  governance  in  externally  funded  development 
projects.  With access to and better understanding of information on ADB policies, procedures, 
and operations, civil society will be able to participate more effectively in ADB operations. Under 
the TA, simplified information packages will be developed and disseminated through the IRM 
web site.  
 
17.    The TA will develop a basic geographic information system (GIS) on ongoing ADB 
projects in Indonesia and those to be processed to allow regional CSOs become aware of ADB 
programs in their jurisdictional areas. 
 
D.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total TA cost is estimated at $375,000 equivalent of which $223,000 is the foreign 
exchange cost and $152,000 is the equivalent local currency cost.  ADB will finance $300,000 to 
cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $77,000 of the local currency cost.  The technical 
assistance will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the ADB-funded TA program.  The 
Government of the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development will provide 
$100,000 in grant financing from the ADB/DFID Partnership for Innovation in Poverty Reduction 
as part of the total ADB financing of the TA.  The Government will bear the balance of $75,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost by providing office facilities, administrative support, and 
remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff and their local transport. The details are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Directorate General of Community and Rural Empowerment (DG-CRE), Ministry of 
Home  Affairs  (MOHA)  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  of  the  TA.  DG-CRE  has  very  strong 
operational capacity in the focus provinces and has been running many training programs and 
developing modules related to participatory development in these regions. This can support the 
information  dissemination  process  and  capacity-building  activities  designed.    DG-CRE  will 
establish a project management office (PMO) at least 1 month before the TA commencement 
and  keep  the  office  fully  functional  during  the  TA  implementation.  A  full  time  staff  of  an 
appropriate level will be assigned to head the PMO and will coordinate and supervise the 
consultant’s  work.    Provincial  government  coordinators  will  be  appointed  to  monitor  TA   
implementation in their regions.  
 
20.  The involvement of both government and civil-society organizations will be crucial for the 
success of the TA. Central PMO staff and the provincial coordinators will work closely with the 
RWGs which are the TA implementing agencies.  Adequate regional government support and 
facilitation  are  essential  for  the  TA’s  success  which  should  be  secured  by  the  provincial 
                                                 
6 The database needs to be available in a variety of forms, including CD-ROM and on the Internet.

5
government coordinators.  The role of each of the key participants in the implementation of the 
TA  will  be  spelt  out  during  the  regional  consultation  workshops  to  ensure  an  effective 
participatory approach is adopted.  
 
21.  Using the simplified technical proposal, ADB will select and engage a firm or consortium 
of international and domestic consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants.  
The  TA  is  estimated  to  require  18  person-months  of  consulting  services  provided  by  one 
international consultant and three domestic consultants. The international consultant will be a 
participatory development specialist and team leader. The three domestic consultants will be (i) 
a  civil  society  development  specialist,  (ii)  information  and  communications  technology   
specialist, and (iii) developer of the CSO database. The consultants will be engaged over a 
period of seven months, which is also the expected TA duration. The consultants’ terms of 
reference are in Appendix 3.  
 
22.  At  least  four  regional  consultation  workshops  will  be  conducted  for  the  technical 
assistance to decide: (i) the process to establish the RWGs, (ii) the process to select the 
members, and (iii) operational procedures for RWGs.  Subsequent workshops will support 
RWGs  activities  including  (i)  CSO  coordination,  (ii)  capacity-building  exercises,  and  (iii) 
consultations  on  regional  development  issues  such  as  the  design  and  implementation  of 
externally funded development projects. The consultants will prepare a brief inception report 
after the first 3 weeks in the field, an interim report at the end of the fourth month, and a draft 
final report at the end of the seventh month of the TA.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $100,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Indonesia  for  Strengthening  Civil  Society  Participation  in  the  Design,  Implementation  and 
Monitoring of Asian Development Bank Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

6

7

8   
Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A. International Consultant 
1.  Participatory Development Specialist / Team Leader (7 person-months) 
The team leader will have the following primary tasks:  
(cid:131) Ensure that the regional working groups (RWGs) are established and well functioning, 
through the following 
(i)  consultations with central Government agencies, regional governments, national 
and regional civil society organizations (CSOs), and external funding agencies; 
(ii)  field  visits  and  consultations  with  regional  governments  (administrative  and 
legislative) and CSOs; and 
(iii)  organization of at least four regional workshops for the following purposes: 
o  identify and select core members in each regional CSO working group, 
o  identify the key tasks related to ADB operations to be performed by the CSO 
regional working groups, and 
o  develop  a support plan for the CSO regional working groups’ ADB-related 
activities. 
(cid:131) Develop a plan on how to disseminate information on ADB policies, procedures, and 
operations to civil society, through information and communications technology, etc. 
(cid:131) Develop a methodology monitoring and evaluation system for project processing and 
implementation, and for disseminating these systems to the general public. 
(cid:131) Supervise a needs assessment of regional participating CSOs to understand capacity- 
building  opportunities  to  ensure  sustainability  of  organizational  efforts  in  local 
development processes. 
(cid:131) Design  a  training  program  module  on  project  management  and  administration, and 
general organization development, along with the module’s implementation strategy. 
 
(cid:131) Organize  one  training  session  on  project  management  and  administration  for  civil- 
society core trainers during TA implementation. 
 
(cid:131) Evaluate the Ministry of Home Affairs’ existing modules, training programs, and overall 
activities related to participatory development, and assess how they can support the 
activities of the TA, and provide recommendations for improvements. 
 
(cid:131) Conduct  regular  discussions  with  Indonesia  Resident  Mission  and  Non-Government 
Organization Center (NGOC) staff in ADB headquarters to ensure that all activities under 
the TA are consistent with ADB’s overall NGO cooperation agenda.

9
B. Domestic Consultants 
1.  Civil Society Development Specialist (7 person-months) 
The specialist will have the following primary tasks:  
(cid:131) Identify and select the regional CSOs most relevant for ADB operations, the CSO’s 
organizational  capacity,  and  provide  recommendations  on  how  to  strengthen  them. 
Support the needs assessment of regional participating CSOs to understand capacity 
building opportunities. 
(cid:131) Develop the criteria to select CSOs most qualified to design, implement and monitor   
ADB projects and ensure that these criteria are widely accepted across a broad range of 
CSOs.  
(cid:131) Develop comprehensive RWG terms of reference, which should describe the process of 
accountability and ensure their acceptability among CSOs.  
(cid:131) Prepare an operations paper on one ADB project that is still in the early stages of 
implementation, and assess and recommend ways that CSOs can help achieve the 
project’s development objectives.  
(cid:131) Prepare an operations paper on one ongoing under performing ADB project, assess   
and recommend ways that CSOs can improve the project’s performance. 
(cid:131) Develop a plan to provide resources (including financial) from internal ADB and external 
sources to maintain the sustainability of the CSO working groups. 
(cid:131) Disseminate to RWGs the most relevant information on ADB experiences in working with 
CSOs in other countries.  
 
2.  Information and Communications Technology Specialist (2 person-months) 
The specialist will have the following tasks:  
(cid:131) Develop a project database in the form of a geographic information system (GIS) for all 
ongoing and future ADB projects in Indonesia. 
(cid:131) Develop  and  implement  a  dissemination  plan  for  the  IRM  website  in  the  selected 
provinces.  
 
3.  Civil Society Organization Database Developer (2 person-months) 
The specialist will have the following tasks:  
(cid:131) Prepare a CSO database in the targeted provinces that are most relevant for ADB or 
other development operations.  Provide contact details and a summary of the CSO’s 
past  project  experience.  Include  national  and  regional  CSOs  that  have  already 
cooperated with ADB. This task will be performed, based on the input and cooperation 
with the civil-society development specialist. 
(cid:131) Place the CSO database on the IRM web site in coordination with the information and 
communications technology specialist and Office of Information System and Technology, 
ADB. 
(cid:131) Ensure that the new database is compatible with the central, web-based NGO database 
by NGOC in coordination with the ICT Specialist.
